abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Management Adjustment
            Credit Project's significant progress was made towards
            achieving the stated objectives and outcomes. The
            project's overall outcome was therefore rated as
            satisfactory. The general lessons learned from this project
            are: Public administration reforms require serious
            government commitment and ownership and are likely to
            succeed if they are homegrown. Reforms that require
            coordination between several agencies require a change in
            work practices and culture. The single-tranche disbursement
            mechanism provides a clear understanding of the prior
            actions that the government needs to undertake. The
            country-specific lessons include: Coordination among
            agencies to achieve a common objective or goal is difficult
            in practice especially in Yemen. In a country with
            relatively low technical capacity, a policy-based adjustment
            credit also needs to be complemented by technical assistance
            that supports all affected agencies. The other lessons
            learned is to set realistic objectives that are clearly
            associated with Credit conditionality. Moreover, major
            changes are needed for the future: a focus on outcomes; a
            focus on poverty reduction objectives in setting expenditure
            priorities; greater attention to incentives, competition,
            and public participation; more access to technical
            assistance in implementation of certain areas; and engaging
            civil society and political leadership in owning and
            pursuing reforms to ensure sustainability overtime.
